messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Edo period Tosho tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich, The trouble with these late tosho is that all they seem to make are the Nobuie revival type which can be a bit boring, although if they are good
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich,
The trouble with these late tosho is that all they seem to make are the Nobuie revival type which can be a bit boring, although if they are good enough to copy the Nobuie glazed surface they are more interesting.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, August 25, 2006 12:19 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Edo period Tosho tsuba


Hi Alan, thanks for that information. I guess thoughts of gimei spring
to mind. I am curious as to the worth of some of these guards, I have a
link to a tsuba by Suishinshi Masahide that is considered I think quite
important. I have linked a scan of the information here

http://www.nihontokanjipages.com//personal/Masahide-tsuba.jpg

I find these guard quite interesting and wonder if for example, Masahide
and his students, being the traditionalists that they were and working
in the old Koto ways, liked to do the full bit, as in make tsuba for
some of their swords as well ?? just like the old Tosho did.

Just speculating.

Cheers

Rich

Alan Bale wrote:
>
> Rich,
> I think tosho signed with much the same signature they used on blades
> although as the kanji are very small the cutting might be different.
>
> If you are thinking about fake tosho signatures on tsuba, I have never
> heard of this happening although we did have a Shinkai tsuba in
> Christie's last sale which was not believed.
>
> There is not a lot in the books as the tsuba are not considered as
> being of much importance.
>
> Alan
>

> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com <mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com>

> to their sword mei ?. Did that have different designations ?, or use
> alternate titles ?, and are there any records, i.e. references or books
> showing Tosho tsuba mei ?.
>
> I have seen various mei on tsuba by Masahide, Naotsuna, Naokatasu and
> they are close, though the papered Naokatsu I have seen show some
> differences. I have also recently come into possession of tsuba signed
> Yasutsugu and Daido. I am looking at buying a Naokatsu tsuba when I am
> in Japan next month.
>
> Some of the greatest mid/late Edo sword smiths had a hand at making
> tsuba and it appears that they, for the most part, did an excellent job.
> I would be interested in any material, references and articles on this
> subject. I have Roberts Haynes' information in the Tsuba, an Aesthetic
> guide and Nihonto Koza but would also like to read anything else that
> might be about the place.
>
> Cheers
>
> Richard Turner

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Edo period Tosho tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, I think tosho signed with much the same signature they used on blades although as the kanji are very small the cutting might be different. If you are
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
I think tosho signed with much the same signature they used on blades although as the kanji are very small the cutting might be different.

If you are thinking about fake tosho signatures on tsuba, I have never heard of this happening although we did have a Shinkai tsuba in Christie's last sale which was not believed.

There is not a lot in the books as the tsuba are not considered as being of much importance.

Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, August 25, 2006 7:44 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Edo period Tosho tsuba


Hi all, it is a bit quiet here so I thought I might run this past
people. Did swordsmiths, that made tsuba, sign any differently compared
to their sword mei ?. Did that have different designations ?, or use
alternate titles ?, and are there any records, i.e. references or books
showing Tosho tsuba mei ?.

I have seen various mei on tsuba by Masahide, Naotsuna, Naokatasu and
they are close, though the papered Naokatsu I have seen show some
differences. I have also recently come into possession of tsuba signed
Yasutsugu and Daido. I am looking at buying a Naokatsu tsuba when I am
in Japan next month.

Some of the greatest mid/late Edo sword smiths had a hand at making
tsuba and it appears that they, for the most part, did an excellent job.
I would be interested in any material, references and articles on this
subject. I have Roberts Haynes' information in the Tsuba, an Aesthetic
guide and Nihonto Koza but would also like to read anything else that
might be about the place.

Cheers

Richard Turner





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Edo period Tosho tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, it is a bit quiet here so I thought I might run this past people. Did swordsmiths, that made tsuba, sign any differently compared to their sword mei ?.
messages.messageBody:
Hi all, it is a bit quiet here so I thought I might run this past
people. Did swordsmiths, that made tsuba, sign any differently compared
to their sword mei ?. Did that have different designations ?, or use
alternate titles ?, and are there any records, i.e. references or books
showing Tosho tsuba mei ?.

I have seen various mei on tsuba by Masahide, Naotsuna, Naokatasu and
they are close, though the papered Naokatsu I have seen show some
differences. I have also recently come into possession of tsuba signed
Yasutsugu and Daido. I am looking at buying a Naokatsu tsuba when I am
in Japan next month.

Some of the greatest mid/late Edo sword smiths had a hand at making
tsuba and it appears that they, for the most part, did an excellent job.
I would be interested in any material, references and articles on this
subject. I have Roberts Haynes' information in the Tsuba, an Aesthetic
guide and Nihonto Koza but would also like to read anything else that
might be about the place.

Cheers

Richard Turner

messages.messageBody:

Elliott
